video_info.title: How Ayahuasca Change My Life - trauma, depression, relationship, finding hope again
video_info.description:

transcript.text: hi guys I'm Emmy today finally I'm going
to share with you guys my iasa
experience it's been eight months and
honestly out of my expectations it
completely changed my life and it was
also the first step that got me out of
depression it took me some time to feel
ready to share my experience on this
fairy public
platform iasa is still not legal in many
countries
where I did it it was legal but it's not
really a socially Wily acceptable thing
I haven't even talk to my parents about
it actually so this video will be the
first time hearing about my experience
so first what is aasa basically it is a
plant-based psychedelics originating
from the Amazon rainforce it is
considered a medicine and has been used
for Centuries by indigenous people from
Colombia Peru Ecuador Brazil still en
rold for healing and therapeutic
purposes to connect with oneself and
also the nature more and more
neuroscientists and even in the hover
studies they begin to study iasa as a
treatment for depression anxiety
addiction and Trauma so everything I
just said I actually did not know when I
book my iasa retreat I did not plan to
do it I did not do any research or watch
any YouTube videos about it how I end up
doing it was actually actually pretty
sudden I had depression earlier this
year I'll talk more in details about it
in a separate YouTube video but during
my depression I didn't know why I was
depressed I know I'm very lucky and very
blessed to live this life and looking
from the outside it would seem like I
have everything I just felt so hopeless
that I didn't know how I could get out
of depression so I was just in this
really dark place and I couldn't see the
light like at the end of the tunnel I
was just trying anything I went to
different therapists nothing seemed to
work so I traveled to Colombia in April
I think in some way I was hoping that if
I just travel far away that maybe it
would get me further away from
depression a friend of mine told me
you're in Colombia why not try iasa and
at first I'm like I no I'm not really
into these psychedelic stues but I
thought you know there's nothing to lose
and my friend also said you have two
options you can either go back to Hong
Kong and start taking anti depressants
because we both knew I couldn't keep
living like that and another way why not
give this a try I was in Meda in at the
time and I just saw the week after
there's a spot in this iasa Retreat
that's just 1 hour away so I bought
myself a 7 Days iasa Retreat I remember
when I look at the website it says you
don't get what you want you get what you
need I remember thinking like what was
that in the end that's what I got there
are also some preparations that it says
you should do one week before you should
stop drinking alcohol if you're on
anti-depressant or anti-anxiety
medication you should stop I was never
on any also cut out red meat so on the
day of the iasa retreat I arrived to the
meeting point where there will be a bus
that takes us into the mountains I think
it's around 20 people for the retreat
and a lot of people like myself went
there alone I was surprised to know that
uh most people they have booked this
Retreat like months or even a year ago
and they have done a lot of preparation
I was like the only one who did it so
spontaneously and that's when I realized
wow it's a big thing it's not just a fun
road trip on the weekend and we arrived
to the location which was beautiful I
mean it's nothing luxurious so the first
night we hadn't taken any Iowaska yeah
we're just getting to know each other it
started with a word Circle actually we
would be doing a word Circle every day
where we all gathered sitting around in
a circle and go one by one to share and
talk about our experience Our intention
talk about why we're here and I still
remember quite a few people shared their
addiction problem or their childhood
traumas when it was my turn I said I
don't really have any trauma I think
that's the beginning of when I started
to learn that traumas are not
necessarily big crazy incidents that
maybe the police is involved that
someone land in jail there are big tees
and there are also small tees for
example as a child if your parents
suddenly yelled at you and say I wish
you were never born that can also be a
significant trauma that affects the
child's life in the long run by the time
I haven't really done much self work so
I wasn't aware of these things we were
each given a journal start writing about
Our intention and also to record our
experience in each iwasa ceremony I
never really Journal before remember
when I first got it I was like oh my God
I need to write can I use my phone to
type but phones were not really
encouraged to use during the ceremonies
because it can bring different trigger
and honestly when you're on an iasa trip
I don't think you would want to be
getting text messages from people and
then responding in a way that you might
regret later the first day was pretty
chill at night we sat around at bonfire
we had really yummy homecooked food this
Retreat is family run it's is not like a
big Resort and they also have a live
music band because music is very very
important in aaska
[Music]
[Music]
ceremonies the way they play the music
really brings out different emotions in
you it's lonely on this
path never looking back in my Su days
Retreat there were four ceremonies two
night ceremonies and two day ceremonies
there were sort of space out throughout
the week and before every ceremony they
would guide us to do a meditation first
at this point I haven't really meditated
my whole life I've always said I'm
someone who cannot meditate I cannot sit
still for even 5 minutes but since I was
already here for I waska why not just
embrace the whole experience so the
first night ceremony I did the
meditation and then we would go up one
by one to the shaman where he would hand
us the iasa drink it comes in like a cup
you would take it and honestly it did
not taste great it would also give you
like a candy so you can immediately have
it in your mouth to get rid of the eyka
taste and they would also give you a
bucket because it's very high chance
that you would perge so the setting was
We're All in This outdoor area each of
us have like a single bed type of
mattress and there's also a blanket and
a pillow on top after you take the iasa
you can lie down you can also sort of
walk around but because the first one is
a night ceremony they don't really
recommend you to go like so far away it
can be unsafe there's also a bonfire in
front with chairs around it you can also
choose to sit there I remember hearing
people throwing up around me you know
normally when that happened maybe the
smell and the sound would also make you
want to show up but because we're all on
IA like you don't really feel that
effect the whole time the live band is
playing the music and with the music
going crazier and crazier I think I
start seeing more things it's almost
like I'm in Another Universe like just
crazy patterns and I start to feel
really sad like a strong sense of loss I
remember that first ceremony for hours I
was just crying so much I thought I had
no tears left and I remember my mattress
was quite close to the bend at one point
someone from the B stood up and so there
was an empty chair there and I was
talking to the chair I remember thinking
like don't leave me don't leave believe
me and the chair is saying to me trust
me and yeah I know I sound crazy right
now but I just want to be honest with
you guys and my stomach didn't feel well
as well I was in toilet for quite a
while I also purged a lot grew up a lot
at one point I couldn't control my legs
and arms like moving in such a crazy way
and I just want to squash my face I so
worried like people around me would
think I'm was crazy the first night was
painful when I finally came out of it I
think it was after maybe 6 to 8 hours it
was already midnight so I just fell
asleep but the next day when I woke up I
thought this could not be good for me
like I don't want to do this anymore all
I felt were extreme negative emotions
not just emotions physically I also felt
so bad so why would I want to do it
again the next day we also had a word
Circle where each of us share our
experiences some people had experience
like me like they also did not want to
do it anymore but some people saw things
they felt connected they had some real
realizations one of the quotes in IA
they always say is the only way out is
through and that really stuck with me
because I had been in depression for a
while and I really want to get out of it
maybe the way to do it is just to get
through this phase and normally I'm not
really a quitter I have to admit that
part of me also just felt embarrassed to
quit out of all the 20 people for
example there's one guy I think he's
like in his 60s it was his first time
out of the country in years because he
was a refugee in the states and he only
just got his passport and then his
decision is to come fly to Colombia to
do this Retreat he was purging the whole
night you could hear he was in distress
as well but he still kept going and I
guess other people showed such strength
that motivated me to give it another
shot the second ceremony is also a night
Ceremony this time was a very very
different experience I remember having
these really Vivid visuals with fire
burning around me I was being buried and
it was my funeral and I was saying
goodbyes to all my loved ones I
literally thought I was dying like this
is it I realized the ow me had to die
for me to rebirth and have a new life
and I think one of the core reasons of
my depression was I didn't like who I
was no matter how many things you have
in life if you don't like who you are as
a person person I couldn't depend my
happiness on other people or other
things before I would think if I
achieved this if I get this done if I
just take all that checklist I would be
happy and I realize there are all these
changes in my life and also within
myself that I need to work on so that I
can live a life where I am proud of
myself and proud of who I am and I just
couldn't keep living the way I used to
live after that realization I felt
lighter like I got the answer that I
needed but one last thing that I saw
that night was that this girl would have
a huge breakdown and the whole place
would turn into chaos and it would be
bright light everywhere and it actually
didn't happen that night the night just
ended peacefully and I thought I I must
be imagining these things the next day I
still wrote that down in the morning in
my journal and then day after was the
third ceremony day ceremony and what I
saw the night before actually happened
this girl she flew into the pulled three
times like we're all on our iasa trip so
we're very sensitive and going through
our own journey and suddenly just heard
this huge sound of someone dropping into
the pool and the staff took her up she
was going like something really bad
happened get off me some of us were
shocked some of us were crying in the
end a few of the staffs had to hold her
down on a chair where the shaman had to
do some work on her and because it all
happened during daytime so the whole
place was bright afterwards when we had
a word Circle I read out my journal of
what I saw the night before that this
would happen I'm so mind blown by it
like it could just be coincidence during
the ceremony because it's the first day
one you see so much more things at night
everything is dark you can hear about
what other people is doing or like
purging but you're mostly just more in
your own head and with a Darkness maybe
brings out more like the dark side in
you that you need to purge out during
the day you see the beautiful nature I
was just looking at like flowers and
plants and I was just so amazed by how
beautiful they were we're up high up on
the mountains but some cows just walk
all the way up and start looking at us
all of us just look at each other and we
start laughing all of a sudden it also
start raining the whole thing just
seemed so ridiculous that we laugh so
much and we dance so much in the rain I
just felt so much love and joy and hope
and connection with all the the guest on
this Retreat that I just haven't felt
for a long time it just made me feel
like there's hope there's light at the
end of the tunnel and I also realized
that no matter what happened or who I am
with in relationship I need to find that
happiness Within Myself first so this
day ended so well we're all so happy
some of us were like yeah like I think
this is it what more can I learn about
myself do we still need the full
ceremony little did we know maybe I was
expecting think I also had to be like a
magic pill because I got to that happy
point that I would be like that for the
rest of my life and of course it's not
and on the fourth ceremony yeah I didn't
get what I want I got what I needed I
went into this darker place again and I
didn't know why I was like where is that
joy and love and happiness why were all
these negative emotions again and I
realize sometimes some things happen in
our childhood or in the past that we
just blocked it out I think as human
beings we're so good at comp part
mentalizing for me my takea away from
the final ceremony was I went into iasa
saying I don't have trauma and actually
it's because they were blocked out in my
memories maybe it's the way I protect
myself there's still so much to work on
like this is not the end what I felt
like I got out of aaska that was so
valuable it was like equals to years of
therapy in this one week of Iowaska
journey I learned so much from why I was
depressed what I need to change in my
life and to unblock some traumas from my
past and to be able to experience Love
and Hope and joy and all these things as
someone who was in depression the life
that I thought I wanted or the person I
thought I wanted to be something was
missing and was out of alignment and I
was seeking external validation from all
the wrong places without finding
happiness and worth in myself and I was
holding on to things so tightly that
were out of my control I need to learn
to let go and trust that there's a
bigger plan for me and like I said iasa
is not a magic pill that's why
integration after the retreat is very
important as well you can also write
down the things you want to change or
little habits that you want to implement
into your life for example I want to
start meditation most mornings I start
with a meditation around 15 to 30
minutes and sometimes even 1 hour
something that I could never do before
but somehow after iasa I guess I
realized the benefits from meditation
it's really life-changing for me I think
naturally am someone who is more
negative like when I wake up sometimes
I'm back to that negative self so for me
meditation really helps elevate my
emotions and my energy as just a much
better way to start the day and I once
heard um Joe dispenser saying one of his
students she won't get up from her
meditation until she feels in love with
life I think that's my goal from all my
meditation and I also changeed the way I
work and create content after that I
actually announc on my social media that
I won't edit any of my photos anymore I
used to edit very heavily smooth my skin
make my eyes bigger my nose smaller my
space smaller until I can pose it the
more you Ed it the more you feel like
there are all these flaws that you need
to fix the more you embrace yourself
without any editing the more you
actually start to love how you look and
also got myself a therapist that I see
weekly and that's a commitment that I'm
making to myself even on days where I
feel like everything is good I still
talk to her because I know that there's
still trauma in my past that I need to
work through and I also made really
really good friends with the whole group
from The Retreat when I went back to
Hong Kong actually went through some
more difficult times but this group gave
me so much support and really guided me
onto the right path and in the end now
now I am completely out of depression I
never once took into depressant even
when I went to a psychiatrist and she
told me that was my only way to go and
so I'm proud of myself for all the
changes and choices I made and I'm so
grateful for this experience as part of
my journey I'm definitely open to do it
again I felt like there's still more to
learn but if you do decide to do it I
would recommend to do it somewhere where
it's legal I think it's very important
to do it with an exp experience Shaman
who's from the Amazon with years of
practice I hope you guys like my sharing
and I'll see you again next time
[Music]
